page.title: 17Sir Robert of Eastchurch
page.content: A figure in{local history}is Sir Robert de Shurland, who died in 1310. He was Lord of Shurland Hall and Minster, Baron of Sheppey and created a Knight Baron during the reign of {Edward I.}The King also rewarded him with Warden of the Cinque Ports. As Knight Baron of the{Manor House he could collect any flotsam he could reach while riding a horse through the ebb-tide. From this may have grown this{legend: Hearing it said that he would be killed by his own horse he had the horse slain and buried on the beach. Many years later he was to fall over the horse's hoof, which was poking out of the ground, and die from his wounds. Today a brass effigy of Robert de Shurland can be found in Minster Abbey.
